column2: Squibs and Discussions
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column right-indent font-largest page-top headchar-capital above-double-space above-line-space

column2: A Note on Typing Feature Structures
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column right-indent font-largest aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Shuly Wintner <sup>∗</sup> Anoop Sarkar <sup>†</sup>
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column right-indent font-largest aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space symbol-dagger headchar-capital

column2: University of Haifa University of Pennsylvania
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column right-indent aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Feature structures are used to convey linguistic information in a variety of linguistic formalisms.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: Various definitions of feature structures exist; one dimension of variation is typing: unlike untyped
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line line-space headchar-capital above-line-space

column2: feature structures, typed ones associate a type with every structure and impose appropriateness
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line line-space headchar-lower above-line-space

column2: constraints on the occurrences of features and on the values that they take. This work demon-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line line-space headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen above-line-space

column2: strates the benefits that typing can carry even for linguistic formalisms that use untyped feature
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line line-space headchar-lower above-line-space

column2: structures. We present a method for validating the consistency of (untyped) feature structure
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line line-space headchar-lower above-line-space

column2: specifications by imposing a type discipline. This method facilitates a great number of compile-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified aligned-line line-space headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen above-line-space

column2: time checks: many possible errors can be detected before the grammar is used for parsing. We have
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified aligned-line line-space headchar-lower above-line-space

column2: constructed a type signature for an existing broad-coverage grammar of English and implemented
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified aligned-line line-space headchar-lower above-line-space

column2: a type inference algorithm that operates on the feature structure specifications in the grammar
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified aligned-line line-space itemization headchar-lower above-line-space

column2: and reports incompatibilities with the signature. We have detected a large number of errors in the
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified aligned-line line-space headchar-lower above-line-space

column2: grammar, some of which are described in the article.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail line-space headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 1. Introduction
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Feature structures are used by a variety of linguistic formalisms as a means for rep-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: resenting different levels of linguistic information. They are usually associated with
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: more elementary structures (such as phrase structure rules or trees) to provide an addi-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tional dimension for stating linguistic generalizations. A variant of feature structures,
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: typed feature structures, provide yet another dimension for such generalizations. It
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: is sometimes assumed that typed feature structures have linguistic advantages over
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: untyped ones and that they are, in general, more efficient to process. In this article
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: we show how typing can be useful also for systems that manipulate untyped feature
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: structures.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: We present a method for validating the consistency of feature structure specifica-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tions by imposing a type discipline. This method facilitates a great number of compile-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: time checks: many possible errors can be detected before the grammar is used for pars-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ing. Typed systems are used in one linguistic theory, Head-Driven Phrase Structure
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: Grammar (HPSG) (Pollard and Sag 1994), and we present here a different application
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line year headchar-capital

column2: of them for theories that employ untyped feature structures. We constructed a type
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: signature for the XTAG English grammar (XTAG Research Group 2001), an existing
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line year headchar-lower

column2: broad-coverage grammar of English. Then, we implemented a type inference algorithm
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: that operates on the feature structure specifications in the grammar. The algorithm re-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ports occurrences of incompatibility with the type signature. We have detected a large
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: number of errors in the grammar; four types of errors are described in the article.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The technique we propose was incorporated into the XTAG grammar development
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: system, which is based on the tree-adjoining grammar (TAG) formalism (Joshi, Levy,
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: ∗ Department of Computer Science, University of Haifa, Mount Carmel, 31905 Haifa, Israel. E-mail:
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space year tailchar-colon

column2: shuly@cs.haifa.ac.il
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest indented-line shorter-tail symbol-atmark headchar-lower

column2: † IRCS, University of Pennsylvania, 3401 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA-19104. E-mail: anoop@linc.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent hanged-line longer-tail symbol-atmark symbol-dagger year tailchar-period

column2: cis.upenn.edu
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest indented-line shorter-tail headchar-lower above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: c 2002 Association for Computational Linguistics
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column right-indent hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space year page-bottom

column2: Computational Linguistics Volume 28, Number 3
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified font-smallest page-top headchar-capital above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: and Takahashi 1975), lexicalized (Schabes, Abeillé, and Joshi 1988) and augmented
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified aligned-line line-blank-line line-double-space line-space year headchar-lower

column2: by unification-based feature structures (Vijay-Shanker and Joshi 1991). Tree-adjoining
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified aligned-line year headchar-lower

column2: languages fall into the class of mildly context-sensitive languages and as such are more
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: powerful than context-free languages. The TAG formalism in general, and lexicalized
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: TAGs in particular, are well-suited for linguistic applications. As first shown by Joshi
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: (1985) and Kroch and Joshi (1987), the properties of TAGs permit one to encapsulate
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified aligned-line year

column2: diverse syntactic phenomena in a very natural way.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The XTAG grammar development system makes limited use of feature structures
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: that can be attached to nodes in the trees that make up a grammar. Typically, feature
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: structures in XTAG are flat: nesting of structures is very limited. Furthermore, all fea-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ture structures in XTAG are finitely bounded: the maximum size of a feature structure
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: can be statically determined. During parsing, feature structures undergo unification as
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the trees they are associated with are combined. But unification in XTAG is actually
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: highly limited: since all feature structures are bounded, unification can be viewed as
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: an atomic operation. Although the method we propose was tested on an XTAG gram-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: mar, it is applicable in principle to any linguistic formalism that uses untyped feature
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: structures, in particular, to lexical-functional grammar (Kaplan and Bresnan 1982).
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail year headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 2. The Problem
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: XTAG is organized such that feature structures are specified in three different com-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: ponents of the grammar: a Tree database defines feature structures attached to tree
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: families; a Syn database defines feature structures attached to lexically anchored trees;
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-semicolon

column2: and a Morph database defines feature structures attached to (possibly inflected) lexical
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: entries.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: As an example, consider the verb seems. This verb can anchor several trees, among
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: which are trees of auxiliary verbs, such as the tree βVvx , depicted in Figure 1. This
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: tree, which is common to all auxiliary verbs, is associated with the feature structure
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: descriptions listed in Figure 1 (independently of the word that happens to anchor it). <sup>1</sup>
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified font-larger aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: When the tree βVvx is anchored by seems, the lexicon specifies additional constraints
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: on the feature structures in this tree:
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-colon above-line-space

column2: seem betaVvx VP.b:<mode> = inf/nom,
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-lower tailchar-comma above-line-space

column2: V.b:<mainv> = +
column3: page=1 xpos=1 ypos=6 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest indented-line shorter-tail line-space headchar-capital above-line-space

column2: Finally, since “seems” is an inflected form, the morphological database specifies more
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: constraints on the node that this word instantiates, as shown in Figure 2.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The actual feature structures that are associated with the lexicalized tree anchored
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: by “seems” are the combination of the three sets of path equations. This organization
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: leaves room for several kinds of errors, inconsistencies, and typos in feature structure
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: manipulation. Nothing in the system can eliminate the following possible errors:
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-colon above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Undefined features: Every grammar makes use of a finite set of features in the
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column right-indent aligned-line line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: feature structure specification. As the features do not have to be declared,
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column left-indent right-indent indented-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: however, certain bogus features can be introduced unintentionally, either
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column left-indent right-indent aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: through typos or because of poor maintenance. In a grammar that has
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column left-indent right-indent aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: an assign-case feature, the following statement is probably erroneous:
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column left-indent right-indent aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-colon above-line-space

column2: V.b:<asign-case> = acc.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail line-space headchar-capital tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 1 We use “handles” such as V.b or NP.t to refer to the feature structures being specified. Each node in a
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numbered-heading1

column2: tree is associated with two feature structures, “top” (.t) and “bottom” (.b) (Vijay-Shanker and Joshi
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest indented-line shorter-tail headchar-lower

column2: 1991; XTAG Research Group 2001). Angular brackets delimit feature paths, and slashes denote
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail year

column2: disjunctive (atomic) values.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
page=1 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column right-indent hanged-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numeric-only page-bottom

column2: Wintner and Sarkar A Note on Typing Feature Structures
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column right-over font-smallest page-top headchar-capital column-bottom above-double-space above-line-space

column2: __Figure 1__
column3: page=2 xpos=-1 ypos=0 Figure-column left-over right-indent box column-top line-double-space line-space figure-area column-bottom above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Figure 1
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column right-indent font-smallest column-top line-double-space line-space string-figure headchar-capital

column2: An example tree and its associated feature structure descriptions.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: seems seem V <agr pers> = 3,
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-lower tailchar-comma column-bottom above-line-space

column2: __Figure 2__
column3: page=2 xpos=2 ypos=4 Figure-column left-indent right-indent box column-top line-space figure-area column-bottom above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Figure 2
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column right-indent font-smallest column-top line-double-space line-space string-figure headchar-capital

column2: The morphological database entry for seems.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Undefined values: The same problem can be manifested in values, rather than
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: features. In a grammar where nom is a valid value for the assign-case fea-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column left-indent indented-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ture, the following statement is probably erroneous: V.b:<assign-case> =
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower above-line-space

column2: non.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail line-space headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Incompatible feature equations: The grammar designer has a notion of what
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: paths can be equated, but this notion is not formally defined. Thus, it is
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column left-indent indented-line headchar-lower

column2: possible to find erroneous path equations such as VP.b:<assign-case> =
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower above-line-space

column2: V.t:<tense>.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail line-space headchar-capital tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Such cases go undetected by XTAG and result in parsing errors. For example, the
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column right-over hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: statement V.b:<asign-case> = acc was presumably supposed to constrain the gram-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column right-over aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: matical derivations to those in which the assign-case feature had the value acc. With
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column right-over aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the typo, this statement never causes unification to fail (assuming that the feature
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column right-over aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: asign-case occurs nowhere else in the grammar); the result is overgeneration.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: On the other hand, if the statement V.b:<assign-case> = non is part of the lexical
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column left-indent right-over indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: entry of some verb, and some derivations require that certain verbs have nom as their
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column right-over hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: value of assign-case, then that verb would never be a grammatical candidate for
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column right-over aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: those derivations. The result here is undergeneration.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
page=2 xpos=9 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-over indented-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numeric-only page-bottom

column2: Computational Linguistics Volume 28, Number 3
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified font-smallest page-top headchar-capital above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Note that nothing in the above description hinges on the particular linguistic
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column left-indent indented-line line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: formalism or its implementation. The same problems are likely to occur in every
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: system that manipulates untyped feature structures. <sup>2</sup>
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column right-indent font-larger aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 3. Introducing Typing
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: The problems discussed above are reminiscent of similar problems in programming
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: languages; in that domain, the solution lies in typing: a stricter type discipline provides
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: means for more compile-time checks to be performed, thus tracking potential errors
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: as soon as possible. Fortunately, such a solution is perfectly applicable to the case of
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: feature structures, as typed feature structures (TFSs) are well understood (Carpenter
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: 1992). We briefly survey this concept below.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail year tailchar-period

column2: TFSs are defined over a signature consisting of a set of of types (Types) and a set
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: of features (Feats). Types are partially ordered by subsumption (denoted “”). The
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: least upper bound with respect to subsumption of t <sub>1</sub> and t 2 is denoted t 1  t 2 . Each type
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: is associated with a set of appropriate features through a function Approp: Types ×
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: Feats → Types. The appropriate values of a feature F in a type t have to be of
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: specified (appropriate) types. Features are inherited by subtypes: whenever F is ap-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: propriate for a type t, it is also appropriate for all the types t’ such that t  t <sup></sup> . Each
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: feature F has to be introduced by some most general type Intro(F) (and be appropriate
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: for all its subtypes).
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Figure 3 graphically depicts a type signature in which greater (more specific)
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail string-figure headchar-capital

column2: types are presented higher and the appropriateness specification is displayed above
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: the types. For example, for every feature structure of type verb, the feature assign-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: case is appropriate, with values that are at least of type cases: Approp(verb, assign-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: case) = cases.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: A formal introduction to the theory of TFSs is given by Carpenter (1992). In-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail line-space year headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: formally, a TFS over a signature Types, , Feats, Approp differs from an untyped
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified font-largest hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: feature structure in two aspects: a TFS has a type; and the value of each feature is a
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: TFS—there is no need for atoms in a typed system. A TFS A whose type is t is well-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: typed iff every feature F in A is such that Approp(t, F) is defined; every feature F in
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: A has value of type t  such that Approp(t, F)  t  ; and all the substructures of A are
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: well-typed. It is totally well-typed if, in addition, every feature F such that Approp(t,
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: F) is defined occurs in A. In other words, a TFS is totally well-typed if it has all and
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: only the features that are appropriate for its type, with appropriate values, and the
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: same holds for all its substructures.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Totally well-typed TFSs are informative and efficient to process. It might be prac-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tically difficult, however, for the writer of a grammar to specify the full information
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: such a structure encodes. To overcome this problem, type inference algorithms have
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: been devised that enable a system to infer a totally well-typed TFS automatically from
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: a partial description. Partial descriptions can specify
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail itemization headchar-lower above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: • the type of a TFS: V.t:verb
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-double-space above-line-space

column2: • a variable, referring to a TFS: VP.b:assign-case:X
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column left-indent right-indent font-largest aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space itemization above-double-space above-line-space

column2: • a path equation: VP.b:assign-case = NP.t:case
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column left-indent right-indent font-largest aligned-line shorter-tail line-double-space line-space itemization above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 2 Some systems could have elaborate mechanisms implemented to deal with each kind of error
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numbered-heading1

column2: mentioned here. But typing provides a single mechanism that handles several different kinds of errors
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest indented-line longer-tail headchar-lower

column2: simultaneously.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
page=3 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column right-indent hanged-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numeric-only page-bottom

column2: Wintner and Sarkar A Note on Typing Feature Structures
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified font-smallest page-top headchar-capital column-bottom above-double-space above-line-space

column2: __Figure 3__
column3: page=4 xpos=2 ypos=0 Figure-column left-indent right-indent box column-top line-double-space line-space figure-area column-bottom

column2: Figure 3
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column right-indent font-smallest column-top string-figure headchar-capital

column2: A simple type
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: • a
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-double-space above-line-space

column2: • a conjunction
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column left-indent right-indent font-largest aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space itemization above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: The inferred feature structure is the most general TFS that is consistent with the
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column left-indent aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: partial description. The inference fails iff the description is inconsistent (i.e., describes
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: no feature structure). See Figure 4 for some examples of partial descriptions and the
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: TFSs they induce, based on the signature of Figure 3.
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-capital tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4. Implementation
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: To validate feature structure specifications in XTAG we have implemented the type in-
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: ference algorithm suggested by Carpenter (1992, chapter 6). We manually constructed
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line year headchar-lower

column2: a type signature suitable for the current use of feature structures in the XTAG gram-
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: mar of English (XTAG Research Group 2001). Then, we applied the type inference
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line year headchar-lower

column2: algorithm to all the feature structure specifications of the grammar, such that each
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: feature structure was expanded with respect to the signature.
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Type inference is applied off-line, before the grammar is used for parsing. As is the
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: case with other off-line applications, efficiency is not a critical issue. It is worth noting,
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: however, that for the grammar we checked (in which, admittedly, feature structures are
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: flat and relatively small), the validation procedure is highly efficient. As a benchmark,
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: we checked the consistency of 1,000 trees, each consisting of two to fourteen nodes.
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The input file, whose size approached 1MB, contained over 33,000 path equations.
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-period

column2: Validating the consistency of the benchmark trees took less than 33 seconds (more
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: than a thousand path equations per second).
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4.1 The Signature
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numbered-heading2

column2: The signature for the XTAG grammar was constructed manually, by observing the
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: use of feature equations in the grammar and consulting its documentation. As noted
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: above, most feature structures used in the grammar are flat, but the number of features
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: in the top level is relatively high. The signature consists of 58 types and 56 features,
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: and its construction took a few hours. In principle, it should be possible to construct
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: signatures for untyped feature structures automatically, but such signatures will of
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: course be less readable than manually constructed ones.
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4.2 Results
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numbered-heading2

column2: Applying the type inference algorithm to the XTAG English grammar, we have vali-
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: dated the consistency of all feature structures specified in the grammar. We have been
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: able to detect a great number of errors, which we discuss in this section. The errors
column3: page=4 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
page=4 xpos=9 ypos=9 single-column left-indent indented-line line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numeric-only page-bottom

column2: Computational Linguistics Volume 28, Number 3
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified font-smallest page-top headchar-capital column-bottom above-double-space above-line-space

column2: __Figure 4__
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=0 Figure-column centered left-indent right-indent box column-top line-double-space line-space figure-area column-bottom above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Figure 4
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column right-indent font-smallest column-top line-double-space line-space string-figure headchar-capital

column2: Inferred TFSs.
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: can be classified into four different types: ambiguous names, typos, undocumented
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-lower

column2: features, and plain errors.
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4.2.1 Ambiguous Names. Ambiguous names are an obvious error, but one that is not
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numbered-heading3

column2: easy to track without the typing mechanism that we discuss in this article. As the
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: XTAG grammar has been developed by as many as a dozen developers, over a period
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: of more than a decade, such errors are probably unavoidable. Specifically, a single
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: name is used for two different features or values, with completely different intentions
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: in mind. <sup>3</sup> We have found several such errors in the grammar.
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column right-indent font-larger aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The feature gen was used for two purposes: in nouns, it referred to the gender,
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-comma

column2: and took values such as masc, fem, or neuter; in pronouns, it was a boolean feature
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: denoting genitive case. We even found a few cases in which the values of these in-
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: compatible features were equated. As another example, the value nom was used to
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: denote both nominative case, where it was an appropriate value for the case feature,
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: and to denote a nominal predicate, where it was the appropriate value of the mode
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: feature. Of course, these two features have nothing to do with each other and should
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: never be equated (hence, should never have the same value). Finally, values such as
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: nil or none were used abundantly for a variety of purposes.
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 3 Recall that by the feature introduction condition, each feature must be introduced by some most
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest indented-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numbered-heading1

column2: general type (and be appropriate for all its subtypes).
column3: page=5 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column left-indent right-indent font-smallest indented-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
page=5 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column right-indent hanged-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numeric-only page-bottom

column2: Wintner and Sarkar A Note on Typing Feature Structures
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified font-smallest page-top headchar-capital above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4.2.2 Typos. Another type of error that is very difficult to track otherwise are plain
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified aligned-line line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numbered-heading3

column2: typos. The best example is probably a feature that occurred about 80% of the time as
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: relpron and the rest of the time as rel-pron:
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-colon above-line-space

column2: S_r.t:<relpron> = NP_w.t:<rel-pron>
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail line-space headchar-capital above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4.2.3 Undocumented Features. We have found a great number of features and values
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numbered-heading3

column2: that are not mentioned in the technical report documenting the grammar. Some of
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: them turned out to be remnants of old analyses that were obsolete; others indicated
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=1 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: a need for better documentation. Of course, the fewer features the grammar is using,
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: the more efficient unification (and, hence, parsing) becomes.
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Other cases necessitated updates of the grammar documentation. For example, the
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: feature displ-const was documented as taking boolean values but turned out to be
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: a complex feature, with a substructure under the feature set1. The feature gen (in its
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower

column2: gender use) was defined at the top level of nouns, whereas it should have been under
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=2 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the agr feature.
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4.2.4 Other Errors. Finally, some errors are plain mistakes of the grammar designer.
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numbered-heading3 tailchar-period

column2: For example, the specification S_r.t:<assign-case> = NP_w.t:<assign-case> im-
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: plies that assign-case is appropriate for nouns, which is of course wrong; the spec-
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=3 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ification S_r.t:<case> = nom implies that sentences have cases; and the specifica-
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tion V.t:<refl> = V_r.b:<refl> implies that verbs can be reflexive. Another ex-
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ample is the specification D_r.b:<punct bal> = Punct_1.t:<punct>, which handles
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the balancing of punctuation marks such as parentheses. This should have been either
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: D_r.b:<punct> = Punct_1.t:<punct> or D_r.b:<punct bal> = Punct_1.t:<punct
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital above-line-space

column2: bal>.
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail line-space headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4.3 Additional Advantages
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column right-indent aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numbered-heading2

column2: Since the feature structure validation procedure practically expands path equations to
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: (most general) totally well-typed feature structures, we have implemented a mode in
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line

column2: which the system outputs the expanded TFSs. Users can thus have a better idea of
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: what feature structures are associated with tree nodes, both because all the features
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: are present, and because typing adds information that was unavailable in the untyped
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: specification. As an example, consider the following specification:
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-colon above-line-space

column2: PP.b:<wh> = NP.b:<wh>
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail line-space headchar-capital above-line-space

column2: PP.b:<assign-case> = nom
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital above-line-space

column2: PP.b:<assign-case> = N.t:<case>
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital above-line-space

column2: NP.b:<agr> = N.t:<agr>
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail line-space headchar-capital above-line-space

column2: NP.b:<case> = N.t:<case>
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital above-line-space

column2: N.t:<case> = nom/acc
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail line-space headchar-capital above-line-space

column2: When it is expanded by the system, the TFS that is output for PP.b is depicted in
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: Figure 5 (left). Note that the type of this TFS was set to p or v or comp, indicating
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line string-figure headchar-capital

column2: that there is not sufficient information for the type inference procedure to distinguish
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: among these three types. Many features that are not explicitly mentioned are added
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: by the inference procedure, with their “default” (most general) values.
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The node N.t is associated with a TFS, parts of which are depicted in Figure 5
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: (right). It is worth noting that the type of this TFS was correctly inferred to be noun,
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column full-justified hanged-line tailchar-comma

column2: and that the case feature is reentrant with the assign-case feature of the PP.b node
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=8 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: (through the reentrancy tag [304]), thus restricting it to nom, although the specification
column3: page=6 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column full-justified aligned-line

column2: listed a disjunctive value, nom/acc.

column2: 5. Further Research
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column right-indent aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: We have described in this article a method for validating the consistency of feature
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: structure specifications in grammars that incorporate untyped feature structures. Al-
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: though the use of feature structures in XTAG is very limited, especially since all fea-
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ture structures are finitely bounded, the method we describe is applicable to feature
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: structure–based grammatical formalisms in general; in particular, it will be interesting
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: to test it on broad-coverage grammars that are based on unbounded feature structures,
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: such as lexical functional grammars.
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: We have applied type inference only statically; feature structures that are created
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: at parse time are not validated. By modifying the unification algorithm currently used
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: in XTAG, however, it is possible to use TFSs in the grammar and apply type inference
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: at run time. This will enable detection of more errors at run time and provide for
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: better representation of feature structures and possibly for more efficient unifications.
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: In a new implementation of XTAG (Sarkar 2000), feature structure specifications are
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line year headchar-capital

column2: not evaluated as structures are being constructed; rather, they are deferred to the final
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=6 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: stage of processing, when only valid trees remain. We plan to apply type inference to
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the resulting feature structures in this implementation, so that run-time errors can be
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: detected as well.
column3: page=7 xpos=0 ypos=7 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
